http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: NTT

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: From your landing place on Ajigaura Beach, the ocean seems to blur into the landscape. But what appear to be rolling waves are actually the hills of Hitachi Seaside Park covered with more than four million blue flowers, a spring spectacle that attracts thousands of visitors. These nemophilas also grow in the western U.S., which has been connected to Ajigaura by submarine cable since 2000. The park shares its name with the Hitachi electronics company, in turn named after a local copper mine that was once the largest in Japan. In the early nineteenth century, it spurred great industrial development, likely providing the raw material for copper telegraph cables, but also damaged crops and forests with air pollution. Hitachi established a cable division in the 1950s and went on to manufacture several underwater networks, including portions of TPC-5 and the Guam-Philippines cable.

Mukilteo, a Native-American name that has come to mean “good camping ground,” has long been a staging ground for circulation and exchange. It was in Mukilteo that 82 Native American leaders signed over large swathes of land to white settlers in the famous Port Elliot Treaty. And as Americans migrated westward, enterprises such as the Puget Mill Lumber Company cleared the land for them, shipping the region’s trees to ports around the world, as far away as Shanghai and Cape Town. Harbour Pointe, a part of Mukilteo once owned by a logging company, was sold to Standard Oil, which planned to use the land for a refinery. Although this plan never materialized, in the 1960s the company put forward a proposal for “Possession Shores,” a master-planned community that would provide, among other things, housing for workers in the world’s largest factory: Boeing’s airplane assembly lot, only a few miles away. After decades, the master-plan has been at least partially realized. The town has upscale homes, an expansive golf course, technology parks, and two undersea cable systems which can take you from the "camping ground" of Harbour Pointe to Alaska, California, and Japan.

“What happens when a friendly beach town opens its port for global communication?” the Grover Beach city website boasts, “You get the perfect place to surf both the waves and the web!” The cable landing here is one of three international gateways nestled in the rolling hills of San Luis Obispo. Like the stations to which it connects, at Harbour Pointe, Washington and Ajigaura, Japan, however, Grover Beach's station was a new node in the undersea network, constructed specifically for the PC-1 Network. The station also remains the west coast’s only undersea gateway to Central America, as it connects to Panama, Mexico, and Costa Rica via the Pan American Crossing. As such, the city pitches itself as the shortest path, with the least travel time, to Japan and South America. Seeking to leverage their position in the cable network, Grover Beach politicians developed a “Technology Master Plan,” applied for Federal stimulus monies, and have branded themselves as the “virtual port” in order to build out the region’s broadband and technology industries.

Shima is a major hub with connections to five active international cable networks and three different cable stations, but it remains largely invisible to local residents. While cables are hidden, several festivals call attention to the surrounding ocean, known for its abundant marine life since at least the eighth century. Every June, a twenty-foot wooden spiny lobster is paraded through the city streets to encourage a bountiful harvest season. And in September, four men carry an oversized waraji (traditional straw sandal) into the ocean, setting it adrift. This ritual is designed to ward off Dandarabocchi, a mythological giant so large that his footsteps create lakes. Afterwards, spectators gather on the beach for dancing and a fireworks display.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies that the associated page is a cable.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Across history, there have been three kinds of cable technology: copper telegraph cables, coaxial telephone cables, and fiber-optic internet cables. To create a page for a new cable, see the reference page for cables.

This cable links two U.S. and two Japanese cities in a closed loop. Originally a joint venture by several telecom companies, Pacific Crossing (and its operating company) was sold to Japan’s NTT Communications in 2009. Both the northern Pacific route and the western segment along the Japanese coast were damaged during the 2011 earthquake.

From 1889 to 1914, this cable was a vital link between Australia and the rest of the British Empire, providing the communications network necessary for international investment in the region’s mineral wealth. The cable station in Broome, “a palatial iron-structure, raised on stone pillars… with a splendid billiard room attached,” survives as a heritage building today, marked with a commemorative plaque detailing its cable history.

Banyuwangi means "Fragrant Water" in Javanese. Landing on its shores in the late nineteenth century, you emerge from vibrant blue waves. A gateway between Asia and Australia, this Dutch colony is a key stopping point for British telegraph cables. In 1871 a link to Darwin was landed here, connecting Australia to the rest of the world through Java’s shores. While more a century in the future, surfers will travel from around the world to ride Banyuwangi’s waves, nineteenth-century cablemen complain that its waters were “uninviting” because of the “ever-present danger of crocodiles and sharks.” Here the cable intersects both turbulent waters and an ancient spiritual history. From the sixteenth to eighteenth century, the city was the capital of the Hindi Kingdom of Blambangan, which controlled the eastern tip of Java before it was taken over by the Dutch. To dig a trench for the telegraph cable to Singapore, native convicts were employed as laborers. But when they unearthed a Hindu Temple from 700 AD, the laborers refused to continue and women, who reportedly were unaffected by the native “superstitions,” had to be called in to complete the job.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Wikivoyage contributors, “Banyuwangi,” Wikivoyage, accessed June 3, 2013, http://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/Banyuwangi.
Wikipedia contributors, “Banyuwangi (city),” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 3, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banyuwangi_(city).

“1871 Java – Port Darwin Cable,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 3, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/Cables/1871Java-PortDarwin/.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The broad, low beaches of Broome, Australia made for an easy cable landing, but were less hospitable to the British men who operated it. Heavy heat made labor difficult, white ants consumed wooden walls, and there was no town with the comforts of civilization. One cableman reflected that this was indeed a “pioneering experience.” Without the assistance of local Aboriginal tribes, the importation of servants from abroad, and the regular call of supply ships, signal traffic would have stopped along the cable to Java. Some of the most arduous work, such as the construction of the men’s quarters, was given to the Chinese workmen. White ant-proof planks shipped in from Borneo were “anti-ant, anti-tool, and anti-Chinese patience,” recalls a cableman, but “proved so hard as to be almost unworkable.” Much later, when the Chinese servants refused to work, the British and their Malaysian crew armed themselves with revolvers and handcuffs, assuring that station operations would continue. Offshore, on the pearling boats that formed Broome’s most prominent industry, similar practices ensured. Here, Aboriginal women were enslaved and forced to dive for pearls, placing their lives at risk. In Broome, the entrance into a global network, whether via the circulation of messages or pearls, depended heavily on the exploitation of people.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1879-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company; Scotia; Edinburgh (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Completed at the end of 1879, this British cable linked colonies in Java to the central hub of Singapore. Technical difficulties and faults in the cable raised the cost of the project so much that additional financing had to be sought from the Australian colonial governments.

A trading post since the second century, the island of Singapore was a hub of exchange for Southeast Asia long before the British settled there in 1819. When the first underwater telegraph cable arrived forty years later, Singapore was a bustling port city, what one nineteenth-century cable survey called “that thriving halfway house between Europe and the East.” Although produced in a factory in London more than six thousand miles away, the Singapore-Muntok cable was insulated with the coagulated sap of trees native to the region. The Malays had used this substance, known as gutta-percha, for generations to make whips and other products. In the 1840s, a Scottish doctor stationed in Singapore took notice of the sap and brought it back to London. Gutta-percha made an ideal electrical insulator and became the material of choice in the cable industry.  By the time gutta-percha-encased wires populated Singapore's waters, demand had all but wiped out the local flora that made its transmissions possible.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Selected sources:
Ken Beauchamp, History of Telegraphy (IEE History of Technology Series). London: The Institution of Engineering and Technology, 2001. 135-8.
Chester G. Hearn, Circuits in the Sea: The Men, the Ships, and the Atlantic Cable. Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers, 2004. 10-11.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Combined with the Tasman 2 and PacRim East cables, PacRim West provided a link between Australia, New Zealand, and existing transpacific networks. To do so, it even had to traverse the Mariana Trench near the coast of Guam. Completed in 1995, its data capacities were designed for an early age of Internet use, but proved inadequate just a few years later. The cable was decommissioned in 2005 and recycled to become part of the APNG-2 network.

Tourists step on a long cable conduit without looking twice, intent on getting to the ruins of a World War II Japanese antiaircraft gun at the far end of Gun Beach. Few realize that Guam's strategic military value during the war was in part due to its undersea cable networks. Even fewer realize that the island remains one of the most connected places in the Pacific, with cables stretching out from its shores to the mainland United States, Asia, and Australia. At the other end of the beach is the Hotel Nikko, one of the early Japanese five-star hotels in the area, a building dependent on the island’s advanced communications infrastructure. At Tumon Bay, undersea cables bisect a material remnant of the Japanese wartime attack and one of the largest indications of Japanese development on the island, two sites with which cable communications are intertwined. The cable conduits themselves are worn down and blend in with the rocks on the beach. In the water their surfaces are smooth, but rippled, like the ocean. In them, one can see traces of the atmospheric and geological currents that have long positioned Guam at the center of transpacific movements.

Oxford Falls is a center of coordination, a place where seemingly opposed forces depend on one another: human and non-human, wired and wireless, and major telecommunications competitors. A relatively rural area north of Sydney, Oxford Falls was a satellite gateway well before it was a hub for wired infrastructure. In 1987, the government-owned Overseas Telecommunication Commission selected this valley for a satellite earth station in part because the surrounding forest, densely vegetated with native species, naturally protected aerial signals from radiointerference. Eight years later, the earth station’s major competitor, Optus, set up a second facility just down the road. As nature shielded human communication and as competitors paved the way for one another, wireless forms also set the stage for wired links. In the years that followed, major international cable networks terminated in Oxford Falls, interconnecting with rather than eliminating the older satellite arrays.
Connecting three cities in French Indochina in 1885, this cable was essential to the transmission of intelligence concerning the Sino-French War in Tonkin.

Haiphong was founded in the year 43 B.C.E. by Lê Chân, a female general of a Vietnamese revolutionary army. In response to increasing Chinese expansion and mistreatment, two sisters from a military family in a rural Vietnamese village overthrew their Chinese overlords, and formed this small, mostly-female army. From here, the Trưng Sisters’ forces expanded southwards and they liberated Vietnam within a matter of months. The Trung rule only lasted three years, after which the Vietnamese would again struggle against Chinese domination until French colonialism overpowered both Chinese and indigenous movements. Haiphong, a name which means “defensive coastal area,” remained a strategic site through these many conflicts. The area’s deep harbor and location at the mouth of Cấm River made it an ideal center for French naval operations. When the French colonies were interconnected by telegraph cables, Haiphong was established as a stopping point for signals between Saigon and Amoy. In Vietnam today, the leaders of the ancient revolutionary uprising remain national heroes, and an imposing statue of Lê Chân stands watch over Haiphong’s waterways.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “French PTT,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 14, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/France/ptt.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Huế is a watery city. Located in the center of the Vietnamese coast, its harbors and lagoons are protected by narrow strips of land that separate them from the South China Sea. The flat, grey-green Perfume River winds inland for a few miles, where it meets a matrix of canals flowing through the heart of the city. In the 17th century, the Nguyen Lords established the seat of their empire here, in a closed citadel on the north side of the river, from which they governed most of southern Vietnam. Everywhere there are monuments to the city’s prominence over the centuries: old tombs of emperors, ancient grey stone gates, carved statues, and brightly colored pagodas. At the beginning of the 1800s, Huế was captured by Emperor Gia Long and made capital of all of Vietnam. It was not until the city became a “French protectorate,” later in the 19th century, that it was linked by its first undersea cable.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 16, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
UNESCO, “Complex of Hué Monuments, ” World Heritage List, http://whc.unesco.org, accessed August 16, 2013, http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/678/.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You might have come here in 1871, when the China Submarine Telegraph Cable company surfaced a cable from Singapore. Or, you might have come along the 1884 cable, brought ashore by the Eastern Extension company. Despite these outlets to British Empire, Saigon remained in the hands of the French, who finally laid their own system at the turn of the twentieth century. Leaving the city, transmission was slow at times: the government controlled the cable station and international messages sent during times of conflict could be delayed for at least an hour in order for censors to approve them. The cable itself comes ashore far from Saigon, about 50 miles away in rural Cape St. James. A report from the local hydrographic office noted that “the station at Cape St. James was a more healthy place than Saigon, [but] it had some drawbacks,” including potential “incursions of wild beasts. Large tigers were constantly prowling in the vicinity of the station… That the danger was not imaginary was proved by the killing of a large tiger on the verandah of the telegraph station.” Although the area is now a sprawling city and home to over 300,000, it continues to be a critical cable hub, with lines extending out to sea just a few miles around the cape.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The JASURAUS cable was an innovative route, planned to connect Port Hedland on Australia's northwest coast with Indonesia in 1997. Yet after the difficulties in laying the system, subsequent cables were directed south to Perth. As JASURAUS's capacity was overwhelmed by the demands of modern Internet usage in the years to follow, it became a mere backup system for Australian traffic.

North of the original telegraph termination point at Weltevreden lies Jakarta’s post-independence cable hub. The area’s swamplands were once the home to the Dutch Fort Zouteland (“saline land”), and during the Japanese occupation of Jakarta during World War II, Ancol was the site of mass executions and burials. In films of the 60s and 70s, Ancol was portrayed as a mysterious and ghostly place. After Indonesia gained independence, the country’s founding President envisioned the transformation of Jakarta into a great international city, and coastal Ancol as a space for recreation, a “showcase of the nation.” His dreams were not recognized for decades, and even then, they came at a price. Developers dredged the nearby coast, destroying a beach that had made it accessible to Indonesia’s underclass, and converted the marshland for recreation facilities. Today, the theme park Ancol Dreamland, Sea World of Indonesia, resort hotels, and beaches are all accessible only with a fee.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.
Telegeography, “Submarine Cable Map,” accessed July 19, 2013, www.submarinecablemap.com.
“Ancol Cable Landing Station,” Submarine Cable Networks: The World of Submarine Cable Systems and Networks, accessed July 19, 2013, http://www.submarinenetworks.com/stations/asia/indonesia/ancol.
James Bamford, The Shadow Factory: The Ultra-Secret NSA from 9/11 to the Eavesdropping on America (New York: Doubleday, 2008).

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You land in the highest tonnage port in Australia, a zone of transit and transition. Vessels crowd the water – shipping boats, cruise ships, tugboats – and navigate slowly around oil wharves hovering farther out at sea. A few hundred kilometers inland, miners harvest iron ore and send it to Port Hedland via one of the many railway lines terminating there. This is a place where resources, both natural and human, are transferred between networks. From 1991 to 2004, the immigration detention facility here held large numbers of asylum-seekers that entered Australia by boat, many Iraqi and Afghan. The JASURAUS fiber-optic cable, laid in 1997, was just one more system that connected Australia to the world, circuiting a high-speed flow of information in and out of the busy port. Yet the process of interconnection was far from easy. To protect it from the port's traffic, the cable company designed an elaborate trenching scheme that would bury the cable fifty kilometers out to sea along a long shallow shelf. After this drawn out and exasperating process, the companies returned to the previous landing, in Perth, for their next cable. More recently, however, plans were floated for another submarine system, this time one in line with the area's history of extraction, linking Port Hedland to liquified natural gas platforms in Australia's Browse Basin.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “Mining revs up again in the Pilbara,” The Sydney Morning Herald, accessed June 19, 2013, http://www.smh.com.au/news/business/mining-revs-up-again-in-the-pilbara/2006/01/10/1136863238766.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Fiber-optic cables encode signals in light and send them down a thread of glass. Although in development since the early 1980s, the conservative cable industry did not lay the first transoceanic network until 1986. The immense capacity of fiber-optics have made possible the Internet as we know it today.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: France Telecom,  Mauritius Telecom,  Orange Madagascar

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Mauritius been a small but important stopping point for traffic across the Indian Ocean. Its visitors never merely pass through – they always leave something behind. In the 1600s, when the island became a waypoint for Dutch ships, generations of sailors and settlers left invasive species that devastated the local ecosystem. The flightless dodo bird and the domed giant tortoise were among the animals to disappear. When the French took possession of Mauritius in 1700s, they set up lucrative sugar plantations and brought in slaves from nearby Madagascar and Africa. And when the British colonized the island a century later, they replaced slavery with a system of indentured servitude, importing thousands of laborers from India. A telegraph cable was brought to the island shortly thereafter, and Mauritius became a stopping point for colonial dispatches between Europe, Africa and Asia. Although Mauritius has been an independent state since 1968, the former pathways of colonial powers have left their mark here: a diverse, multi-ethnic population, a connection point for transoceanic travelers, and a hub for communications infrastructure. Today, fiber-optic networks link to the edges of the island and data centers are nested in its interior.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Australian Cables,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 25, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Australia/.

Bill Glover, “The Evolution of Cable & Wireless, Part 3,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 25, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/CandW/EATC/.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 25, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Australia/.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As you emerge from the ocean in Sainte-Marie you hear the roar of airplanes above you and the murmur of French conversation all around. Although it is located off the coast of Madagascar, Réunion is one of the oversea departments of France and is therefore part of the same political, financial and social systems as the mainland. Even with less than a million inhabitants, this small island is linked by two different cable networks, giving its Internet a security and speed largely unknown to other remote locales. Accordingly, Réunion has been marketed as a gateway for Western entrepreneurs to develop business around the Indian Ocean without having to deal with the infrastructural disparities or cultural differences they might find on the African continent. From its inception as a colonial trading port to today, Réunion has been a waypoint for the movement of Western goods, information, and influence into Africa and India. From here, you might move via cable networks to the nearby island of Mauritius, or all the way across the Indian Ocean.

Built in 2009 by French telecom subsidiaries, this 1,000 km cable connects French Réunion with Madagascar and Mauritius. In 2012 it was expanded to include Kenya, providing an important node in the African broadband network.

Completed in 1913 in tandem with the Penang-Colombo link, the project was part of a larger Eastern Extension Telegraph Company initiative to improve the ease of transmission for messages sent across the British colonies.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Was located at 44 Northam Road, now Jalan Sultan Ahmad Shah.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In George Town at the turn of the 19th century you witness the beginnings of a modern city. The streets are lined with warehouses and ghauts, wide steps leading from the street to the water. Banks, trading areas, and emporium stores are beginning to appear along Beach Street. Since its founding by the British East India Company in 1786, the town has grown into a bustling trading port and commercial center. George Town has been built on water: its commercial center stands on a swampy wetland that was leveled and filled in the early 1800s. English settlers built their bungalows high up on top of Penang Hill, forbidding natives to do the same. The settlers’ wealthy Chinese business partners were allowed to build in the middle part of the hill. The cable – part of the emerging modern city – surfaces close to the water, but ultimately connected those who lived far above it.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Visions of Penang Archives Online (My Heritage My Penang), accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.visionsofpenang.com.my

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Telegraph Bay, Pok Fu Lam, Hong Kong

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Barty-King: from here they connected to Eastern Extension office at Marine Hour – on the site occupied by Old Mercury House in 1979.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In nineteenth-century Hong Kong, a barrage of undersea cables – from Singapore, Shanghai, Fuzhou, Manila, Labuan, and Macau – landed at Telegraph Bay. From here, cables wound inland across the island’s northern shore, through the city center to the busy Eastern Extension cable office. The daily work of cablemen at “Electra House,” as it was called, was eventful. Traffic was re-directed from one network to another, messages linked local commerce into a global economy, and important political information was relayed about British-Chinese relations. Yet as they sustained the network, cablemen also worried about sustaining themselves. They were concerned about finding healthy food (one worried that local vegetables were not clean enough to eat) and about catching the plague (another remarked that “Hong Kong would not be Hong Kong if we didn’t have an epidemic of something every year”). And leading up to World War II, a cableman recounted, “Life in Hong Kong has been subject to rude jolts during recent years… we had quite a few delightful moments dealing with traffic which poured in for places which had been 'interrupted by bomb.'” Not long after, station life would be interrupted completely when the Japanese took over the island. Today the work of Hong Kong’s cablemen has moved to the island’s southern shore, but Telegraph Bay remains a center of information exchange. It is now the location of the expansive Cyberport, a “creative digital community” built to foster technology development.

This cable was originally laid in 1905 by Germany and connected the Micronesian island of Yap with American-held Guam. In 1916 the Japanese military seized the cable and redirected the link from Yap to Okinawa, extending their communications network in the region.

A century ago, Yap was a Pacific communications hub, the junction point of three cables linking Guam, Shanghai, and Manado. Colonized by Germany, it was a critical node in their vast cable network of over 18,000 miles. Yap also formed an important bridge between America and China. From Guam, the United States relied on the German-Netherlands network to connect to Shanghai. During World War I, the Japanese seized the island and Yap became not only a “cable threat,” but a threat to the sea route between the U.S. and the Philippines. After the war, the possession of Yap, its cables, and its coaling station was the subject of a dispute between the United States and Japan. Japan claimed that the island had been designated to her under a Mandate of the League of Nations. The United States sought to put Yap under “International supervision” as an international cable station, rather than under control of a single nation. After a year of deadlock, the United States and Japan came to an agreement that split the network, and subsequently eliminated all cable links. Today, Yap remains without cable systems and without high-speed Internet infrastructure, linked only via wireless technologies. A single satellite station carries all of Yap’s Internet traffic out of the country.

You have landed on the shores of Okinawa Island, just one island in an archipelago about 300 miles south of the rest of Japan and only 200 miles northeast of Taiwan. Geographically and politically separated from the other Japanese islands, Okinawa remained more or less self-governing until the Meiji Restoration, when it became a target for Japan’s expansionist aims. After winning the Sino-Japanese War in 1895, Japan immediately began laying cables to its colonial territories, including one that linked to Taiwan via Okinawa. For this endeavor, Japan even built its own cable ship, the Okinawa Maru. Following the massive destruction of World War II, Okinawa remained a cable hub, but the station was located far from the island's commercial center, perceived as more vulnerable to attack. Unlike the expansionist telegraph network, the coaxial and fiber-optic projects were collaborative international endeavors. Kokusai Denshin Denwa, Japan’s telecommunications company, partnered with American, Filipino, Chinese, and Korean companies to make Okinawa a stop on numerous transoceanic networks. Several cables continue to have a life even after they became obsolete, now carrying geophysical observations rather than telephone calls.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Originally named Yangon in the 1700s, “end of strife” in Burmese, the city’s name was perverted to “Rangoon” under colonial rule. Under supervision of the British, Rangoon was built to be a political center and commercial hub, with trade ships traveling almost twenty miles down its river to the Gulf of Martaban. When a cable was brought ashore in 1877, connecting the city to Penang, Rangoon was a gridded, western-style city, with sprawling parks, wealthy suburbs, lakes, and hospitals. The telegraph office was established in a large, four story red brick building with ionic columns marking the entrance. Although the British rule ceased in 1948, following great strife and a protracted struggle for independence, the building still stands today. Myanmar's first and, as of 2015, only fiber-optic link, lands about 75 miles south in coastal Pyapon. As in the colonial era, however, Yangon’s inclusion in the cable system is heavily dependent on external support: it is only one small stop in a globe-spanning network.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Stretching a total of 24,000 miles between 39 landing sites, Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 3 (SeaMeWe-3) is more than twice as long as its intercontinental predecessor, SeaMeWe-2. The optical cable system was commissioned in 2000 by an international consortium of nearly 100 corporate investors.

Laid in mid-1938, this Taiwanese-Chinese link came into operation in the midst of growing conflict between the China and Japan. Foreign colonialists and businessmen reporting on the region worried both about civilian casualties and well as falling telegraph prices between the warring countries.

“CABLE SITUATION AT AMOY. MUCH DISCONTENT” reads the headline in a 1931 Singapore newspaper. “The prosperity of business in Amoy largely depends upon its rapid communications by cable to the South Seas,” the article explains, but telegrams “intended for Amoy are now relayed to Shanghai.” Service was disrupted when, a few days prior, Chinese officials shut down the Great Northern Telegraph Company office on Kulangsu Island, where a Danish cable stopped on its way from Hong Kong and Shanghai. This cable originally bypassed Amoy, but in 1873, the company added a branch to the city without Chinese permission and began profiting from the added traffic. When China took control of the Kulangsu-Amoy connection in 1931, it disrupted local businesses already heavily reliant on submarine telegraphy.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Midway between Taiwan and China, this chain of small islands is strategically important. As a result, even though they are sparsely populated, the Penghu Islands have long been linked to communications networks. In the late 1880s, at the order of the Qing governor of Taiwan, a telegraph cable connected Penghu to China in the east and Taiwan to the west. This was accompanied by gun emplacements meant to fortify the “militarily indispensible” island. Despite these measures, less than ten years later the islands were ceded to Japan along with Taiwan, a result of China’s defeat in the Sino-Japanese war. The Japanese would remain in Penghu throughout the first half of the twentieth century, laying cables that linked across the Taiwan Strait. While the connected cities grew busy with international trade, the Penghu Islands remained apart from the action, with most ships and signal traffic merely passing through. Today, the islands are linked to the rest of Taiwan via another kind of subsea technology: major undersea power cables link Penghu into Taiwan’s electric grid.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This French-subsidized, British laid line of 1884 connected what was then called Tonquin to the central communications hub in Hong Kong. The project followed closely after France’s declaration to establish Tonquin, its newest “frontier,” as a French protectorate.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This system, established in 1926, was one of a new breed of "continuously loaded" cables. These cables dramatically expanded the capacity of the telegraph network, in some places offering speeds of over 2000 letters per minute.

Typhoons and loneliness were the greatest perils for the cablemen working on the Cocos Islands in the early and middle twentieth century. Like Midway Island, the Cocos were largely uninhabited before the establishment of a cable station in 1901. The station was built at the highest point on the island: two meters above the high water mark, but this didn't keep it from damage during cyclones in 1907, 1911, and 1933. These caused flooding, collapsed palm trees onto the cable station houses, and wreaked havoc for international communications. During quieter moments, cablemen played tennis, staged theatrical performances, and waited eagerly for the arrival of supply ships every three months to bring food, mail, and mild excitement. Today, tourists seek out the Cocos for their quietude and isolation, sparsely and silently scattering themselves across the white beaches and blue-green waters. Floating just above the ocean’s surface, with no hills or mountains, these low-lying islands will face flooding in the coming years as climate change brings ashore ever-more intense storms.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: At the beginning of the twentieth century, Cottesloe turned to the ocean. The Perth-Freemantle Railway, opened just two decades before, had brought settlers and visitors to the coast. Beach-going was only a newly popular pastime, but by the early 1900s, thousands visited Cottesloe’s shores each weekend. Pine trees endemic to Norfolk Island, a Pacific island also populated by undersea cables, were planted to enhance the beach’s appeal. Around the same time, the Eastern Extension Cable Company extended a link across the Indian Ocean to Cottesloe. On the shore, they built a multi-story red brick building, where the signals came in as quickly as ocean waves. In 1937, the cable station manager boasted that “the only time throughout the entire year when there is a cessation of activity in these stations, is on Armistice Day, when the instruments are closed down for a period of two minutes.” Even though they were separated from the city of Perth, cablemen remained connected to urban life via the copper wire, at least until July 31, 1966, when the station finally closed. The cable itself remains, stretching across Cottesloe’s sandy beach, its insulation unfurling as it decays.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You arrive at a cable station fit for a king. Constructed for the landing of a new fiber-optic network, one cable industry leader recalls that the Tungku station was “built as a palace” so that it could be inaugurated by the Sultan of Brunei. In the following years, the massive station would become a hub of links to Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines, followed by connections reaching as far as the U.S. and Western Europe. When a link to the Asia-America Gateway in 2009 created an oversupply of bandwidth, the Brunei government sold it to international carriers in order to finance new cable landings. Located a few miles north of the capital, the station is at once remote and central, surrounded by trees but also a highway exchange and the campuses of both the University of Brunei and an international boarding school. Across the street, a fifteen-story glass office tower (and the second tallest building in the country) contains the headquarters of local telecom provider DataStream Technology Group. When cables first arrived on nearby Tungku Beach in the 1990s, illegal sand mining had caused severe erosion. But the jagged shoreline has been restored and is now a popular place for watching sunsets.

Asia-America Gateway (AAG), opened in 2009, was the first high-bandwidth optical cable to provide a direct link between Southeast Asia and California (via the Philippines, Guam, and Hawai'i). Positioned further south than other trans-Pacific routes, AAG avoids the seismically active areas near Taiwan where earthquakes are known to cause cable disruptions.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Kuala Muda station in Penang, commissioned in the early 1980s by Telekom Malaysia (TM), was the country’s first landing site for underwater telephone cables. As the westernmost point on the Malay Peninsula, the state of Penang made a logical terminus for the Indian Ocean Commonwealth (IOCOM) cable from Chennai, completed in 1981. While Penang’s nineteenth-century telegraph connections surfaced in the bustling heart of colonial George Town, IOCOM and subsequent cables landed ten miles north in a comparably remote area where the Muda River flows into the Malacca Strait. By placing the station on the outskirts, TM minimized the risk of cable damage from anchors and trawls of passing ships. Today, the company controls all four of Malaysia’s cable hubs (and five smaller stations), similarly positioned in fishing villages and beach towns on the urban fringe.

Entering service in 1997, the FLAG (Fiber-Optic Link Around the Globe) Europe-Asia cable system connects the United Kingdom with Japan via more than a dozen landing sites. The cable, now operated by an Indian telecom, was the subject of a 1996 Wired magazine article by cyberpunk author Neal Stephenson in which he traveled to “six countries and four continents trying to get a grip on this longest, fastest, mother of all wires.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The landing site at Ban Pak Bara in Satun province is Thailand’s only cable hub on the west coast and thus handles much of the country’s signal traffic to Europe and the Middle East. Yet the area was linked to the global network only recently, in the late 1990s, when the FLAG cable project negotiated for a new station to be built on Thai shores. From Ban Pak Bara, the cable layers pioneered an extensive route overland to the historical landing at Songkhla, directly linking submarine networks in the Andaman Sea and Gulf of Thailand for the first time. Although a key international node, the station remains overshadowed by its natural surroundings. From your landing place on the white sand beaches of this small fishing and agricultural community, you can see modest cinderblock communications buildings and towers across the road, surrounded by acres of mangrove trees. And looking back from where you came, your view is dominated by the lush and mountainous islands of Mu Ko Phetra National Park rising out of the water.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Since the 1880s, Chikura has been known for precision exercises tied to the ocean. Every year, a knife ceremony is held at a local shrine dedicated to the gods of seasoning and culinary arts. Seven or eight men fillet and plate a whole carp using nothing but a twenty-inch blade and a pair of foot-long chopsticks, honoring the town’s legacy as a fishing community. In 1989, Chikura became a site of underwater cable innovation. The first fiber-optic line between the U.S. and Japan landed here, less than fifty miles from central Tokyo, followed by many other cables in the 1990s and 2000s. More recently, the town has become a surfing hub. Several professional competitions are held on Setohama Beach, where well-formed waves crash opposite the prominent cable station.

The consortium-owned Southeast Asia Japan Cable (SJC) runs from Singapore to Japan, with branch connections to Thailand, Brunei, the Philippines, Hong Kong, and China. Intense demand along the communication route prompted capacity upgrades less than a year after it was built in 2013.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: For decades, Taiwan’s cables have been concentrated at its northern and southern tips. While the Tanshui and Toucheng stations are on the fringes of Taipei, the Chunghwa Telecom station is located in the rural southern township of Fangshan. Most traffic to Southeast Asia, whether from Taiwan, East Asia, or North America, passes through the Bashi Strait, the narrow passage separating Taiwan and the Philippines. Fangshan was the ideal gateway to this route until recently, when a spate of natural disasters severed numerous cable links. An earthquake in September 1999 broke Taiwan’s terrestrial backbone, one undersea cable, and caused cell sites and radio relays to collapse. During the 2006 Hengchun earthquake, submarine landslides took out nine undersea links. Most recently, Typhoon Morakot disrupted six international cables and 1,700 wireless base stations, in addition to taking 500 lives. Fangshan, perched on the edge of the Bashi Strait, is no longer a popular interconnection point for undersea traffic.

Completed in 2000, the consortium-owned China-U.S. Cable Network was the first direct cable route between the two countries. It consists of dual Pacific crossings, forming a ring structure with connections along the west coast of the U.S. and between several Southeast Asian hubs. Only a year after it entered service, however, the anchor of a fishing boat off Chongming Island disrupted much of the traffic between China and the U.S..

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before it was a cable hub, Katong was a center of private wealth in British Malaya. Colonial elites established giant mansions, coconut plantations, and weekend villas along the waterfront in this East Singapore district from the early nineteenth century onwards. Though some of these structures have been preserved and restored, often painted bright colors, the still-affluent neighborhood has also seen some major physical transformations. The beach where you emerge from the APCN-2 network didn’t even exist before the 1970s. It was created as part of a massive land-reclamation project designed to add more space for housing on the island. Modern apartment towers and Singapore’s largest park now occupy the expanded coastal area. Soon after the artificial beach was completed, a telephone cable arrived from Hong Kong, followed by connections to regional fiber-optic networks in the 1990s and early 2000s.

The Asia-Pacific Cable Network links several nodes around the China Seas. Initially completed in 2002, it has suffered multiple failures caused by undersea earthquakes and structural faults despite the cable’s “self-healing ring” design. Fortunately, the network's disruption has not typically halted Internet access, due to area's many redundant pathways. Nevertheless, the Internet can slow to a crawl when the APCN-2 is down.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This Korean city has long been a hub for Japanese connections. In the nineteenth century it served as Japanese merchants’ primary access point to Asian trade networks. When it opened, Busan’s Japanese-run telegraph station became an equally important gateway. It handled all Korean telegraph traffic until an overland link to Seoul was completed in 1888, and it allowed Japanese-language telegrams to leave the country for the first time. Cable traffic spiked from a few thousand messages sent between the two countries in 1884 to some 430,000 — the vast majority in Japanese. In 1931, Busan was the site of Japanese experiments for another communications revolution: the use of undersea cables for voice transmission. Today, the city’s two cable stations, which provide a major gateway to the Internet, are finally operated by Korean companies. Yet the country faces another challenge at its shores – from local aquaculture rather than foreign powers. Dense seaweed forests immediately off Busan’s coast twist around ropes bordering the cable’s path. Harvesting the seaweed, fishermen come dangerously close to the country’s international communications lines. Whenever cable companies land a new system, they have to be careful not to disturb the fragile seaweed’s growth. Each cable must be carefully placed in a “mattress” before it is lowered down into the crop.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: China Telecom,  China Unicom,  Chunghwa Telecom,  KT,  Verizon Business,  NTT,  AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Appropriately named Keoje, Korean for “great crossing,” this island is the landing site of several international submarine cable networks, though it is still smaller than the hub in nearby Pusan. As you come ashore through clear waters, the sound you hear is not heavy rainfall but the pebbles on Hakdong beach tumbling in the surf. Named after a crane (“hak” in Korean), this wing-shaped beach sits in a valley covered by flowering camellia plants, sheltered from the industrial shipyards and granite mines further north. Eschewing the discrete architecture of many contemporary cable facilities, the Korea Telecom landing station calls attention to itself with an ornate design. Decorative columns and topiaries line the station’s brick and glass entryway, which faces away from Hakdong’s beachfront promenade.

In 2008, Qingdao hosted the sailing regatta for the Beijing Olympic Games. Teams from forty countries navigated a racecourse in the Yellow Sea, not far from where underwater cables surface in Fushan Bay. To realize its vision of a “Broadband Olympics,” China Netcom extended the East Asia Crossing cable to its Qingdao landing station at the same time. While the Olympics may have prompted this connection, there are other reasons to bring cables here. China’s northernmost hub, Qingdao lies midway between the financial centers of Beijing and Shanghai. Compared to hubs in South China, it offers more direct access to networks spanning Korea, Japan, and the United States. Even in the colonial era, the port was coveted for its strategic location. Germany kept a naval base outside the city, then called Tsingtau, until Japan seized control at the start of World War I.

Constructed in 2008 by a consortium of six telecom companies, the Trans-Pacific Express (TPE) cable is a major link between sites in the South China Sea (China, South Korea, and Taiwan) and the west coast of the United States. An extension to Japan opened in 2010. It greatly increased connection speeds across the Pacific, bringing them up to those found in trans-Atlantic cables.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: EAC-C2C represents the merger of the EAC (East Asia Crossing) and C2C (City-to-City) cable networks, completed in 2007 by Pacnet. Together, they form Asia’s largest privately owned cable system with a total of seventeen landing sites across Japan, Korea, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Singapore.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You can journey to the village of Maruyama along cables from the U.S., Australia, or various sites in Southeast Asia. But upon reaching the station, you may feel as if you’ve traveled even farther—and back in time. Across the road is Rosemary Park, a detailed replica of a sixteenth-century English town. Built in 1997 by British architects, the tourist attraction includes a working windmill, formal gardens, a duck pond, and a recreation of Shakespeare’s childhood home, complete with lifelike statues and time-specific furnishings. Shakespeare referenced rosemary in his plays, and Maruyama is known for producing this and other herbs. While the park looks to the past, the modern cable station is one of Japan’s most popular landing sites. Both enact a kind of virtual transit to far-off locales.
In 1900 the German post and telegraph service laid their own system between Tsingtau and Shanghai.

As a key British treaty port in the wake of the first Opium War, Shanghai rapidly developed as a contact zone for international powers. The city brought together a mix of cultures, architectural styles, and social classes, but these connections were made possible by the exploitation of Chinese labor and a concession system that granted foreigners immunity to Chinese law. The first telegraph cable arrived in 1871, covertly brought ashore in the middle of the night by the Great Northern Telegraph Company. In the ensuing years more cables were laid without official Chinese sanction. Without the cooperation of the Chinese people, however, cables remained vulnerable to disruption. Enterprising pirates stripped cables for resale. Local villagers ripped down lines that disturbed ancestral grave sites and the landscape’s feng shui. Men armed with rifles had to patrol the Yangtze River to stop sailors from throwing anchor and severing the cable. The situation was ameliorated by degrees when, in 1875, the Chinese government offered official recognition and protection to the cables in exchange for ownership of the illegal lines upstream of Shanghai. A period of relative stability followed, as China slowly developed an overland monopoly on telegraph lines while colonial powers built ever more underwater connections.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When China began to struggle against imperialism in the late 1800s, Qingdao was an important node of resistance. The Boxers, an anti-imperialist, proto-nationalist Chinese movement, had a strong presence in area, and in 1897, the Chinese government began building up a military base here to protect against foreign invasion. Shortly thereafter, German troops seized and occupied this fort. After a year of fighting, China conceded the area to Germany, who re-named the city Tsingtau, a French transliteration of the original name. This small Chinese fishing village was transformed into a German administrative and economic center, with tall three-story stone buildings, wide streets, electricity, and a navy base. At the turn of the century, two telegraph cables were landed, one connecting to Tschifu and one to Shanghai. Today, two major cable systems continue to land at Qingdao, linking the city to Korea and across the sea to California.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You land in Nasugbu only a day after a typhoon has swept through the area, devastating local infrastructure and flooding many homes built on the broad beach. This small town, strategically located on the South China Sea only sixty miles from metro Manila, is the largest network hub in the Philippines. From here, direct circuits link to almost every Asian country. In the 1990s, the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company opened the country’s first international fiber-optic cable station, which towers over the palm trees and bamboo structures that line the beach. Just down the street is Globe Telecom’s newer facility, an anchor point for the Southeast Asia-Japan cable system. Large walls surround both stations, yet the place where cables enter the water is unmarked. On your journey back out to sea, you pass the remains of a Spanish galleon, sunk by the Dutch navy in 1600. Discovered in 1992, the shipwreck became one of the most important finds in underwater archeology. A replica, along with a museum and resort, were built on nearby Fortune Island but have since fallen into disrepair.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Launched with great fanfare in 2008, the Matrix Cable System promised to mark “the elimination of the digital divide in Indonesia” by linking Jakarta, Singapore, and Batam. The price for Internet services has fallen significantly due to the cable's increase in network capacity.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Đà Nẵng is a city divided by a river. Before the first bridge was built in 2000, residents had to take a ferry between the eastern shore, the site of the former French colonial settlement, and the western peninsula, which shelters the city from the sea. The peninsula was once home to poor fishermen, but many have since moved away as beach resorts populated the coast – these extend south several kilometers to the site of Đà Nẵng’s international cable station. Like Vung Tau to the south, Đà Nẵng had long been connected to undersea networks, first as part of the French colonial cable system and later as part of the Americans' wartime communications strategy. Đà Nẵng’s international cable station, however, was the first built with the support of the national telecommunications carrier, Vietnam Posts and Telecommunications. While the city's infrastructures, from bridges to cable systems, bring connections, they also bring the expansion of capitalism, providing benefits to some at the expense of others.

In 2012, a consortium of telecom companies led by China Unicom signed a construction and maintenance agreement for the Asia-Pacific Gateway (APG) cable system, due to open in 2015. The system is specially routed to avoid areas prone to seismic activity while providing additional capacity along the region’s existing international networks.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: NTT,  PLDT,  Telekom Malaysia,  Starhub

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Telekom Malysia (TM) cable landing station at Mersing is situated on an otherwise undeveloped beach roughly six miles south of the town center. Large signage on a curved, blue glass awning and a flag bearing the TM logo ensure that the site is highly visible from the coastal highway that passes nearby. Since the late 1990s, it has housed cables linking southeastern Malaysia to the rest of Asia, the U.S., the Middle East, and Western Europe. On their journey east, these cables intersect the offshore Seribuat Archipelago, for which Mersing’s ferry terminal is the main point of departure. As Malays, tourists, and communication signals are carried out to sea, north-south trade routes link Mersing to the rest of the Malay Peninsula as a site of tin, rubber, and palm oil production.

In 2012, Telekom Malysia (TM) contracted with the Japanese company NTT Communications to run two of the six optical fiber pairs of the Asia Submarine-cable Express (ASE) system connecting Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Japan. The portion of the network owned by TM is branded Cahaya Malaysia (“cahaya” is the Indonesian word for “light”).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pacnet

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Tseung Kwan O, known in English as “Junk Bay” for the many fishing boats that once dotted its waters, is now a booming tech center. As is true for much of urban Hong Kong, this area is built upon reclaimed land and the nearby Tseung Kwan O Industrial Estate extends over fill where the bay used to be. The Industrial Estate, one of many set up by the Hong Kong Science & Technology Parks Corporation, is the headquarters of Hong Kong's largest television broadcaster. It also houses the content of a significant slice of the Hong Kong Internet: twelve major data centers are located here, including those of HSBC, the Japanese firm NTT Communications, and Telehouse Hong Kong. Signals transit in and out of the data centers to destinations around the world via four submarine cables that land here. Behind the Industrial Estate, however, in the enormous South East New Territories landfill, the debris of such accelerated flows remain.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When it was finished in December 2005, the consortium-owned Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 4 cable provided both additional bandwidth and greater redundancy along the bulk of the previous-generation SeaMeWe-3 line between the Mediterranean and Singapore. SeaMeWe-3, however, extends significantly further to points in China, Japan, Australia, the U.K., and Germany, among others.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As a landing site for the 1983 ASEAN cable, Songkhla was the first station in Thailand to receive underwater telephone links. Cables surface on the seemingly idyllic Ban Kao Seng beach near the country’s largest natural lake, the same place where invading Japanese troops landed at the start of the Second World War. Years earlier, according to local folklore, a wealthy governor from the south of Thailand was sailing up the coast with a fortune in gold when his ship ran aground near Ban Kao Seng. Stranded, the governor ordered his fortune buried, committed suicide, and left instructions for his severed head to be placed on the rocky cliffs above the beach. The name Kao Seng derives from the treasure’s supposed value: 900,000 baht. Some believe it’s still buried there alongside several underwater cables entering the Gulf of Thailand.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Surfacing at Sinduri beach, Taean, you may think you’ve been transported to the shores of California or Australia. In fact, Sinduri is home to Korea’s only sand dunes, formed thousands of years ago by winds sweeping inland from the sea. The grains still have trace amounts of oil from a massive spill in 2007, roughly one-third the size of the Exxon Valdez disaster. Set back from the beach on a small peninsula, Sinduri’s cable station received its first fiber-optic link in 1996, but it was not until the arrival of the East Asia Crossing cable a few years later that the only landing site on Korea’s west coast became a hub in a major international network.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: American Samoa Government,  Elandia

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Your path from Hawai‘i via American Samoa brings you to a cable station housed within the curved, glass and metal headquarters of SamoaTel, the country’s primary telecom provider. Built in 2004 and connected to the underwater network five years later, the facility is located about a quarter mile inland from Apia’s exposed harbor, making it less vulnerable to tropical cyclones. One of the earliest recorded storms occurred in 1889 when colonial powers were vying for control of the islands. Engaged in a tense standoff in the port, German, British, and U.S. ships were destroyed by massive waves after they refused to evacuate. Several additional cyclones hit the low-lying city in the 1990s and early 2000s, causing severe flooding and damage to infrastructure. Gale-force winds also disrupted satellite communications, motivating investment in a more resilient submarine link.

Propelled by a strong wind, you land on a small, white sand beach dotted with coconut palms and volcanic rock formations in the southern part of Tutulia Island. This spot is now linked to Hawai'i by underwater cable, but the same connection was once made by air. During World War II, the U.S. Navy built an airfield here, which was later converted to receive passenger jets. By the 1960s, it had become a key stopping point for flights between Australia and Hawai‘i. As planes grew larger in the 1980s, however, they started to land at the expanded airport in nearby Samoa or bypass the islands entirely, no longer needing to refuel midway along their journeys. Today, the runways are mostly used by military and cargo transports with only the occasional passenger flight, making the U.S. territory feel remote. The cable didn’t do much to change this, since few locals can afford the steep Internet fees.

This two-part cable system links American 'Samoa and Samoa to Keawa'ula, Hawai'i, where it joins networks reaching the U.S. mainland, Southeast Asia, and Australia. To lower costs, the system repurposed sections of the PacRim East cable between Hawai'i and New Zealand, built in the 1990s as one of the first fiber-optic trans-Pacific links and retired in 2007. Despite being nearly 20 years old, the cable provides more than enough capacity for these small island groups.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The CKC (China-Korea Cable), completed in 1996 and since decommissioned, was the first underwater optical telephone cable to connect China and Korea. Its opening was commemorated by a Chinese postage stamp featuring a blue and green map of the two landing sites at Qingdao and Taean. The sites are marked by silhouettes of traditional buildings and are joined by a thin red line. A brightly colored cable, complete with pulsing light waves and a metallic signal repeater, runs across the bottom of the stamp.
